item.title: A study conducted by INSEAD has discovered that when shareholders vote on CEO accountability, it leads to higher company returns
item.description:
A new study titled “Say Pays! Shareholder Voice and Firm Performance,” published in the Review of Finance, suggests that shareholder votes do improve CEO accountability and reduce unnecessary spending within corporations. The study’s author, Maria Guadalupe, an Associate Professor at INSEAD, found that previous research on the impact of “say-on-pay” policies was inconclusive, possibly due to focusing on periods after say-on-pay became law. Guadalupe’s research examined 250 instances where shareholders of S&P 1500 companies proposed to adopt say-on-pay policies between 2006 and 2010, before such votes were mandatory...

item.title: CEOs anticipate a deceleration in economic growth in 2020
item.description:
Global CEOs are expressing unprecedented pessimism regarding the economic outlook for 2020, according to PwC’s 23rd Annual Global CEO Survey. 53% of CEOs anticipate a decline in economic growth, a significant increase from 29% in 2019 and a stark contrast to the mere 5% who held this view in 2018. This marks the highest level of pessimism since the survey began in 2012, with only 22% of CEOs predicting economic growth in 2020, down from 42% in 2019...

item.title: Accenture says that CEOs must lead the effort to reskill their employees
item.description:

item.title: Various approaches to talent management in Asia
item.description:
Source: ECN. Attracting and retaining skilled managers in Asia has become increasingly crucial for business leaders. A recent survey by the Economist Corporate Network (ECN) of 550 member companies in Asia revealed that 95% of CEOs actively engage in talent management practices.
